RWD

I late 2011, the term responsive web design was being thrown around a lot and gaining traction. It wasn‘t until late 2011 when front-end developer +steveavery sent the office this article. NB: it’s not fully responsive in that the media itself is the same for all broswers, but i’m limited by the CMS. with more flexibilty i would have used retina.js

Tooling

Looking back at the source code for this makes me realise how useful all the build tools we have are. In 2012 I’d write long-hand, vanilla CSS, meticulously indent my CSS (and manually create a .min), write all my vendor prefixes out. 

Hanging punctuation wasn’t a big thing in 2010 and I don’t recall a single template on ant publishing platform that used it. Fast-forward to 2015 and it’s more common — the biggest one being on Medium.

Georgia Pro

After sampling a near hundred webfonts, I settled on this. Its generous x-height means it performs well at the small sizes (copyright, captions, etc). It’s a very stable, sober looking face, without being too stiff. body copy set in serifs easier to read.

Known unknowns

This was the first site I designed that sat on top a content management system. This means that, although we could limit and guide content, we ultimately have no control over it.

When print material is designed, all content is available to the designer up front. They know excatly what they're working with and it's another reason why high-end print design looks so seductive. I'm not making excuses here but getting a nice type rag or making images look good on user generated content is one order tougher.
